channel.title: BBC News - Entertainment & Arts

item.title: Nicki Minaj and husband Kenneth Petty sued by sex assault victim
item.description: The woman claims the couple harassed her to try to make her recant accusations against Kenneth Petty.

item.title: Sarah Rainsford on Russia: 'I've been told I can't come back - ever'
item.description: The BBC's Sarah Rainsford, who is being expelled from Russia, speaks about the country she loves.

item.title: Strictly Come Dancing: Ex-rugby star Ugo Monye completes 2021 line-up
item.description: Ugo Monye will join Olympic swimmer Adam Peaty and 13 other stars when the show returns next month.

item.title: Nanci Griffith: Folk and country singer-songwriter dies aged 68
item.description: The Grammy-winning artist was best known for her influential career in folk and country music.

item.title: Una Stubbs: Sir Cliff and Cumberbatch remember 'wonderful' actress
item.description: Sir Cliff Richard and Benedict Cumberbatch praise the late actress, who has died at the age of 84.

item.title: Banksy confirms East Anglian seaside artwork is genuine
item.description: The secretive artist claims responsibility for pieces along England's east coast.

item.title: Britney Spears' father to step down as conservator
item.description: Jamie Spears pledges to take part in an "orderly transition" but doesn't say when that will happen.

item.title: Music stars and festivals sign up to UN initiative to combat harassment
item.description: The UN Safe Spaces Now initiative is backed by Anne-Marie, Clara Amfo and Glastonbury's Emily Eavis.

item.title: Lord of the Rings: Amazon moves show to UK from New Zealand
item.description: The multi-million dollar production is one of the most expensive shows in the history of television.

item.title: Johnny Depp: San Sebastian Film Festival defends honorary award
item.description: The San Sebastian Film Festival reacts to claims that it is disrespecting domestic abuse survivors.

item.title: 'Hybrid' is the future says Edinburgh International Book Festival chief
item.description: As the Edinburgh International Book Festival begins, its director says online audiences and guests will remain important.

item.title: Picasso masterpieces to go on sale in blockbuster auction
item.description: Proceeds could reach $100m in what is thought to be the most valuable auction of the artist's works.

item.title: Batman: Robin coming out as bisexual was 'missing piece' of story
item.description: The Batman comics writer says addressing Robin's sexuality was the "missing piece" of his story.

item.title: Shetland’s biggest gig – the day Pulp flew in to Lerwick
item.description: At the height of their fame, the Britpop icons travelled to Lerwick to play a show for just 1,400 fans.

item.title: Coda: 'Deafness is not a costume you can put on,' says film director
item.description: The maker of the film Coda says being authentic to the story of child with deaf parents was vital.

item.title: Nick Grimshaw: 'I'm leaving Radio 1 in a leap of faith'
item.description: The legendary presenter reflects on leaving BBC Radio 1 after 14 years.

item.title: Bloodstock: Heavy metal fans emotional at festival's return
item.description: Last year's edition had to take place online, but head-bangers are enjoying the big comeback.

item.title: Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis poke fun at cleanliness debate
item.description: The Hollywood couple caused a stir last month by saying they didn't fully bathe their kids every day.

item.title: Lily Allen on feeling like theatre's 'village idiot'
item.description: The singer is temporarily pausing her successful music career to star in a brand new play 2:22.

item.title: The Orielles: How the band turned their album into a film score
item.description: The band on surreal gigs at cricket grounds and the "happenings" that inspired their new project.

item.title: Stephen Lawrence drama 'celebrates common decency'
item.description: Steve Coogan says it was an honour to play the man who helped convict two men for the teen's murder.

item.title: How TV's The Windsors is making its unregal stage debut
item.description: The creator and cast of the royal comedy satire take us behind the scenes of their West End show.

item.title: Adam Peaty: I'm going to be very uncomfortable on Strictly
item.description: The Olympic champion is the latest to be announced for the show.

item.title: Reading: Teacher gets stories published after 46 years
item.description: Keith Godwin used to make up stories for his pupils in the 1970s, now they have been published.

item.title: Kiwi Chow: The film-maker who took Hong Kong's protests to Cannes
item.description: Kiwi Chow's documentary was a surprise at the film festival - and it has a controversial title.

item.title: Virtual reality: 'There's no max, there's no limit!'
item.description: "There's no max, there's no limit" to virtual reality, so is it the future of live music?

item.title: Fashion photographer: 'The world doesn't see this part of Afghanistan'
item.description: Fatimah Hossaini is a fashion photographer in Afghanistan and wants to use her work to help women be seen.

item.title: Peter Kay charity shows: Cancer patient 'honoured'
item.description: Sometimes laughter is all you've got, says Laura Nuttall, who is receiving treatment for brain cancer.
